articles.title: Multi-qubit nanoscale sensing with entanglement as a resource
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 26 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09760-yControlling pairs of nitrogen vacancy centres enables the measurement of magnetic correlations below the optical diffraction limit, and the use of entangled pairs shows a linear scaling of the measurement sensitivity with readout noise, as opposed to the quadratic scaling that would be obtained with unentangled spins.
articles.content: Nitrogen vacancy (NV) centres in diamond are widely deployed as local magnetic sensors, using single-qubit control to measure both time-averaged fields and noise with nanoscale spatial resolution1. Moving beyond single qubits to multi-qubit control enables new sensing modalities such as measuring nonlocal spatiotemporal correlators2 or using entangled states to enhance measurement sensitivity3. Here we describe protocols for using optically unresolved NV centre pairs and nuclear spins as multi-qubit sensors for measuring correlated noise at nanometre length scales. For noninteracting NV centres, we implement a phase-cycling protocol that disambiguates magnetic correlations from variance fluctuations, leveraging the presence of a third qubit, a 13C nucleus, to effect coherent single-NV spin flips and enable phase cycling even for co-aligned NV centres that are spectrally unresolved. For length scales around 10 nm, we create maximally entangled Bell states through dipole–dipole coupling between two NV centres and use these entangled states to directly read out the magnetic field correlation, rather than reconstructing it from independent measurements of unentangled NV centres. Importantly, this changes the scaling of sensitivity with readout noise from quadratic to linear. For conventional off-resonant readout of the NV centre spin state (for which the readout noise is roughly 30 times the quantum projection limit), this results in more than an order of magnitude improvement in sensitivity. Finally, we demonstrate methods for detecting high spatial- and temporal-resolution correlators with pairs of strongly interacting NV centres.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in quantum sensing technology using entangled nitrogen vacancy centers in diamond, which enables nanoscale magnetic measurements with greatly improved sensitivity. This advancement has broad implications for precision measurement and quantum technologies, offering tangible benefits beyond a niche audience. The article provides detailed context on the methods and impact, fulfilling criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: New quantum sensor boosts nanoscale magnetic measurements using entangled diamond defects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists use tiny defects called nitrogen vacancy (NV) centers in diamonds to measure magnetic fields at very small scales. These sensors usually work with single quantum bits (qubits), but controlling multiple qubits together can improve how well they detect magnetic signals.

**What happened** – Researchers developed a method to control pairs of NV centers and nearby atomic nuclei to measure magnetic noise with very high detail. By creating special linked states called entangled Bell states between two NV centers about 10 nanometers apart, they could measure magnetic correlations directly. This approach improves the sensitivity of measurements, making them more accurate even when the reading system has noise.

**Impact** – This new method changes how the measurement accuracy improves as noise changes, making it much more efficient. For example, it can be over ten times more sensitive than older techniques. This is a big step because it allows scientists to study tiny magnetic effects that were hard to detect before, which can help develop better quantum technologies and sensors.

**What's next step** – The team plans to use these entangled NV pairs to explore even more detailed magnetic patterns at the nanoscale. This could lead to new tools for studying materials, biology, and quantum devices with unmatched precision.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using entangled diamond defects, scientists have created a new quantum sensor that measures tiny magnetic signals with much higher accuracy than before.

articles.title: New evidence shows the Maya collapse was more than just drought
articles.summary: Researchers studying Classic Maya cities discovered that urban growth was driven by a blend of climate downturns, conflict, and powerful economies of scale in agriculture. These forces made crowded, costly city life worthwhile for rural farmers. But when conditions improved in the countryside, people abandoned cities for more autonomy and better living environments. The story turns out to be far more complex than drought alone.
articles.content:
Why do people choose to settle in cities, and what motivates them to leave? Modern urban areas continue to gain and lose residents for many reasons, including economic pressures, congestion, lifestyle shifts, pollution and, at times, major public health events.

It appears this pattern has existed for a very long time.

Early Cities and Agrarian Life

The first cities around the world were created by rural communities. These early residents were farmers, or agriculturists, who depended on land-extensive forms of production. Their livelihoods encouraged them to live in small, scattered settlements to reduce the effort and time required to reach their fields.

Even in ancient times, however, urban life was costlier in many respects. People living in cities faced higher exposure to infectious diseases that spread easily in crowds, greater competition for land and essential resources and increasing inequality. Surprisingly, many farmers still accepted these drawbacks and chose city life.

What explains this choice?

Investigating a Long-Running Debate

UC Santa Barbara archaeologist Douglas Kennett, who has spent years examining the development of Classic Maya cities, notes that researchers have debated this question for decades. According to Kennett, the explanation is complex and involves several intertwined factors that contributed to both the growth and eventual decline of these ancient urban centers.

Kennett and colleagues from multiple institutions examined this issue in detail in a study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Their work applies population ecology theory to quantify the forces that shaped urbanization across the Classic Maya Lowlands.

Forces Behind the Rise of Maya Cities

"We determined that the rise and expansion of Classic Maya cities resulted from the interaction of climate downturns, intergroup conflict and the presence of strong economies of scale realized through capital investments in agricultural infrastructure," Kennett said. "These factors promoted the coevolution of urbanism, systemic inequality and patron-client relationships in cities."

Using the same analytical approach, he explained, the team also identified the conditions that triggered deurbanization. According to their findings, people began to leave "when the benefits of urban living no longer outweighed the costs, as environments were degraded near cities and climate amelioration improved the livability of rural areas where people would have more freedom and autonomy."

Climate, Conflict and New Data

The researchers originally focused on the role of climate change, particularly drought, in the decline of Classic Maya cities. Since 2012, the team has compiled archaeological information on population shifts, conflict and investments in agricultural systems. Their work gained new momentum when high-resolution climate records became available.

"We also capitalized on major developments in computational modeling that allowed us to look at the relationships between these datasets in ways not previously possible," Kennett said.

A Unified Model of Urban Change

The study brings together several previously competing explanations for ancient urban growth and decline, including environmental pressures, warfare and economic dynamics. It does so in a single, flexible model grounded in population ecology. This framework also helps explain why agrarian societies, which normally benefit from living spread out, sometimes gathered in cities despite the financial and social costs.

"The biggest surprise for me was that the abandonment of cities occurred under improving climatic conditions," Kennett noted. "We have long thought that the decline of Classic Maya cities partially resulted from an extended period of drought. It turns out to be a much more complicated and interesting story."

Insights for Understanding Urban Evolution

Overall, the research offers valuable guidance for interpreting both past and future patterns of urban growth and decline. By identifying broad principles that influence how populations concentrate and disperse, the study contributes to a deeper understanding of urban evolution across different eras and environments.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding the complex factors behind the rise and fall of Classic Maya cities, using advanced computational modeling and interdisciplinary data. This research has broad implications for urban studies and human-environment interactions, offering valuable insights into urban evolution that can inform future societal planning and sustainability.

articles.title: This smart catalyst cracks a challenge that stumped chemists for decades
articles.summary: Using a smart computational search, scientists discovered a catalyst ingredient that finally makes tough alkyl ketones behave the way chemists want. The reaction now runs cleanly and reliably, opening the door to faster and easier molecule-building.
articles.content:
Ketones appear throughout organic molecules, which is why chemists are eager to create new reactions that take advantage of them when forming chemical bonds. One reaction that has remained especially difficult is the one-electron reduction of ketones needed to generate ketyl radicals. These radicals are highly useful intermediates in natural product synthesis and pharmaceutical research, but most available techniques are designed for aryl ketones rather than simpler alkyl ketones. Although alkyl ketones are far more common, they are also naturally harder to reduce than their aryl counterparts. With this challenge in mind, a team of organic and computational chemists at WPI-ICReDD at Hokkaido University has developed a catalytic strategy that finally enables the formation of alkyl ketyl radicals. The study appears in the Journal of the American Chemical Society and is available open access.

In earlier work, WPI-ICReDD scientists showed that a palladium catalyst paired with phosphine ligands could drive light-activated (reaction activated by shining light) transformations of aryl ketones, but the same system did not work for alkyl ketones. Their data indicated that alkyl ketyl radicals did form briefly. However, these radicals immediately returned an electron to the palladium center, a phenomenon known as back electron transfer (BET), before any useful reaction could proceed. As a result, the starting material remained unchanged.

Similar to traditional palladium-based catalysis, the behavior of photoexcited palladium catalysts is highly dependent on the phosphine ligand attached to the metal. The team suspected that choosing the correct ligand might unlock reactivity with alkyl ketones. The difficulty was scale: thousands of phosphine ligands exist, and experimentally screening them for an unfamiliar reaction would be slow, labor-intensive, and generate unnecessary chemical waste.

To overcome these limitations, the researchers turned to computational chemistry to narrow down the field of candidate ligands. They used the Virtual Ligand-Assisted Screening (VLAS) approach developed by Associate Professor Wataru Matsuoka and Professor Satoshi Maeda at WPI-ICReDD. Applying VLAS to 38 phosphine ligands, the method produced a heat map that predicted how well each ligand might promote the desired reactivity by analyzing electronic and steric properties.

Guided by these predictions, the team selected three ligands for laboratory testing and ultimately identified L4 as the most effective option -- tris(4-methoxyphenyl)phosphine (P(p-OMe-C 6 H 4 ) 3 ). This ligand successfully suppressed BET, allowing alkyl ketones to generate ketyl radicals and participate in high-yield transformations.

The resulting method provides chemists with an accessible way to work with alkyl ketyl radicals and demonstrates how VLAS can rapidly guide the development and optimization of new chemical reactions.

This advancement overcomes the trade-off between multi-level capability and power efficiency, paving the way for next-generation storage memory with broad implications for data storage technology and energy consumption in data centers. The article provides sufficient technical context and references to demonstrate the substance and significance of the achievement.
articles.personality_title: New ferroelectric transistors cut power use in NAND flash memory
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NAND flash memory is a common type of storage used in devices like smartphones and computers. It stores data by holding different electrical charges in tiny cells. However, making these memories store more data while using less power has been a challenge.

**What happened** – Scientists have developed ultralow-power ferroelectric field-effect transistors (FeFETs) to improve NAND flash memory. These new transistors use special materials that switch electric charge more efficiently. This lets memory cells hold multiple levels of data without using as much energy as before. The research was published online in Nature on November 26, 2025.

**Impact** – This breakthrough allows NAND flash memory to store more data at lower power levels, which is important because data centers and electronic devices use huge amounts of electricity. By overcoming the usual trade-off between storing many data levels and saving power, this technology could lead to faster, longer-lasting, and more energy-efficient memory devices.

**What's next step** – Researchers will work on integrating these ferroelectric transistors into commercial memory products. This includes testing their durability and compatibility with existing manufacturing methods. If successful, we can expect new storage devices that consume less power and hold more data in the near future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New ferroelectric transistors enable NAND flash memory to store more data while using much less power, marking a key step toward better and greener storage technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouveaux transistors ferroélectriques réduisent la consommation d’énergie des mémoires NAND flash
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La mémoire NAND flash est un type courant de stockage utilisé dans les smartphones et ordinateurs. Elle stocke les données en retenant différentes charges électriques dans de très petites cellules. Cependant, augmenter la capacité de stockage tout en réduisant la consommation d’énergie est un défi.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont développé des transistors à effet de champ ferroélectriques (FeFET) à très basse consommation pour améliorer la mémoire NAND flash. Ces nouveaux transistors utilisent des matériaux spéciaux qui changent de charge électrique plus efficacement. Cela permet aux cellules mémoire de stocker plusieurs niveaux de données sans consommer autant d’énergie. Cette recherche a été publiée en ligne dans Nature le 26 novembre 2025.

**Impact** – Cette avancée permet à la mémoire NAND flash de stocker plus de données tout en consommant moins d’énergie, ce qui est important car les centres de données et les appareils électroniques utilisent beaucoup d’électricité. En dépassant le compromis habituel entre capacité multi-niveaux et efficacité énergétique, cette technologie pourrait conduire à des mémoires plus rapides, durables et économes en énergie.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont travailler à intégrer ces transistors ferroélectriques dans des produits mémoire commerciaux. Cela inclut des tests de durabilité et de compatibilité avec les méthodes de fabrication actuelles. Si cela réussit, on peut s’attendre à de nouveaux dispositifs de stockage consommant moins d’énergie et offrant plus de capacité bientôt.

**Phrase clé** – De nouveaux transistors ferroélectriques permettent à la mémoire NAND flash de stocker plus de données tout en réduisant fortement la consommation d’énergie, une étape clé vers des technologies de stockage meilleures et plus écologiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevos transistores ferroeléctricos reducen el consumo de energía en memorias NAND flash
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La memoria NAND flash es un tipo común de almacenamiento usado en smartphones y computadoras. Guarda datos reteniendo diferentes cargas eléctricas en pequeñas celdas. Sin embargo, aumentar la capacidad de almacenamiento mientras se reduce el consumo de energía ha sido un reto.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos han desarrollado transistores de efecto campo ferroeléctricos (FeFET) de muy bajo consumo para mejorar la memoria NAND flash. Estos transistores usan materiales especiales que cambian la carga eléctrica de manera más eficiente. Esto permite que las celdas de memoria guarden varios niveles de datos sin usar tanta energía. La investigación fue publicada en Nature el 26 de noviembre de 2025.

**Impacto** – Este avance permite que la memoria NAND flash almacene más datos usando menos energía, lo cual es importante porque los centros de datos y dispositivos electrónicos consumen mucha electricidad. Al superar la dificultad entre almacenar múltiples niveles y ahorrar energía, esta tecnología podría crear memorias más rápidas, duraderas y eficientes.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores trabajarán para integrar estos transistores ferroeléctricos en productos comerciales. Esto incluye probar su durabilidad y compatibilidad con los métodos de fabricación actuales. Si tienen éxito, pronto veremos dispositivos de almacenamiento que consumen menos energía y tienen mayor capacidad.

**Frase clave** – Nuevos transistores ferroeléctricos permiten que la memoria NAND flash guarde más datos usando mucha menos energía, un paso importante hacia tecnologías de almacenamiento mejores y más ecológicas.
